author: Phillipa Yalden
title: Two dead after blackspot crash
text:
Two dead after blackspot crash PHILLIPA YALDEN Last updated 11:32, February 3 2017 MIKE BAIN/FAIRFAX NZ 
Police were called to the crash at the intersection of State Highways 1 and 29 - otherwise known as the Tauranga turnoff at Piarere - at 9.50am on Friday. 
Two people from the same vehicle have died in a two-car crash at a high risk intersection near Karapiro, in Waikato. 
Another person from a second vehicle was trapped in the car with serious injuries. 
That person had since been cut free and was being taken to Waikato Hospital by ambulance. 
Police were called to the crash at the intersection of State Highways 1 and 29 - otherwise known as the Tauranga turnoff at Piarere - at 9.50am on Friday. 
Two fire trucks from Putaruru and Tirau, five police cars and ambulance were at the crash scene about 10 metres from the intersection towards Cambridge. 
The T-intersection was a busy 100kmh stretch of highway and the main route between Hamilton and Tauranga. 
Bay of Plenty police Senior Sergeant Mike Membrey said both people died at the scene. 
Police were in the process of notifying next of kin. 
Initial reports were that one vehicle was pulling out of SH29 when it was struck by a vehicle travelling on SH1, Membrey said. 
That would be confirmed by Serious Crash Unit which was onsite to investigate, he said. 
Police completely closed the section of road. 
"We ask that people are patient and follow the directions of emergency services at the scene while detours are being set up," police said. 
Road users travelling south from Cambridge could use Karapiro Road, State Highway 29 and State Highway 27. People travelling north could turn off at State Highway 27 and follow the signposted detour. 
It was not known how long the road would be closed. Update: Both SH1 and SH29 are CLOSED. A detour is in place. Motorists are advised to expect delays in the area. ^LC https://t.co/FsePNqD49t pic.twitter.com/NmAJtc12HI â€” NZTA Waikato/BoP (@NZTAWaiBoP) 2 February 2017 

In the past decade, there have been 13 deaths and 45 serious injuries from crashes on the stretch of road. 
The Transport Agency had announced that $8.1 million would be spent on improving safety from the Cambridge section of the Waikato Expressway to the SH1/SH29 intersection. 
Waikato highways manager Niclas Johansson said the work would provide immediate safety improvements ahead of a detailed investigation to identify long-term solutions for the 17km section of State Highway 1, including the intersection. 
The project included creating a wide centreline to reduce head on crashes, installing side barriers in high-risk areas to reduce the impact of run-off road crashes, and upgrading signs to make high risk areas more visible. 
Membrey urged motorists to try and avoid the area and delay any travel for the next few hours. 
"We are heading into a long weekend - enjoy yourself, take your time when driving and allow extra time to travel. If you need to take a break."
